content.description:
The 50 meter Y Slab has been scrubbed by avalanches and snow creep, rendering a clean, easy slab studded with pockets for protection and jugs for gripping. The Right Y is a beautiful pitch of 5.5. Left of the Left Y is a classic 5.8- and the Left Arête is 5.6, even the overhang has big holds and good protection.

The hardest we could find was a 5.10 mini arch, overhang at ground level.

4th class up an easier 2nd pitch; then scramble left or right to trail at Petzolt Caves.

Or sling white bark pine at 55m and rap.
content.protection: 1 to 2 sets cams, 1 set wires for pro and anchor. (no fixed anchors) scramble off left. Long sling for a tree at 55m if rapping.
content.location: In the Grand Teton avalanche path west of Spalding Falls. Y Slab obvious.

content.description:
White House Boulder is the large, white, east, northeast facing bloc on the South Fork of Garnet Canyon route, below West Hourglass Coulior. The problems were established by Josh Larson and crew. The left leaning crack feature, G.W. is around V6 and the right arete is the hard, Abe Lincoln, V11, SDS.

5:35

vimeo.com/132637670
content.protection: Flat snow in May and June is the best for the original route. The hard, low ball arete has an easy landing. In dry condition more pads are required. A snow shovel might be nice in early season.
content.location: Hike to the meadows of Garnet Canyon and head toward the South Fork, 300m above the meadows campsites is the bloc on the left, south.

climbs.name: Subalpinist
climbs.fa: Greg Collins, Brandon Gust, Paul Kimbrough, Nate Opp

content.description: NW arête of Hourglass Coulior, Nez Perce peak, Garnet Canyon Meadows. A short, 15 m., 5.9 corner leads to a nice, white rock, belay ledge. Then a 5.12- arête pitch that overhangs severely, but has big holds and good protection. A 5.6 pitch can lead to the top.
content.protection: 2 finger and 2 rattly finger size cams, 1 small cam, 6 cams total, and 13 quick draws, some longer quick draws.
content.location: The overhanging NW arête of the hourglass coulior above the Garnet Canyon Meadows. Hike up avalanched talus and or seasonal snow to a white ledge and alcove under the overhang. Climb multicolored right facing corner to obvious white ledge. Continue up and right on overhanging arête.

content.description: Overhanging buttress of dark red colored rock east of West Hourglass Coulior, lower Nez Perce Peak. A right trending crack and plated line.
content.protection: A long pitch of steep rock. 2 + sets, runners, long draws.

content.description:
From the right to the left, follow roof crack system. 5.11 then 5.12b. 2nd pitch 5.9 r

-

Beautiful ambience under the cave.

-

Historic shelter from all but the biggest winter avalanches.
content.protection: 115 m. 2 pitches, 4 protection bolts, 2 bolt anchor, hand drilled, several fp's. Cams with rattly-hand size for end of crux pitch, small technical cams for the start, a 70m rope is recommended.
content.location: See photo. East face Middle Teton above Garnet Meadows

content.description: Just west of lunch rocks, Garnet Canyon Meadows, 15 m above Grand Teton 'trail', is a  South facing overhang with a left angling 'crack'. This is a short top rope route on jugs, crimps, slopers and liebacks.
content.protection: Top rope. This will eventually become either an x-rated route or it could receive 2 pieces of fixed protection.
content.location: Just west of lunch rocks, Garnet Canyon Meadows, 15 m above Grand Teton 'trail', is a  South facing overhang with a left angling 'crack'.

content.description:
The Largest boulder in Garnet Canyon Meadows.

Nice problems above flat campsites.
content.location: Mostly problems on the north and west sides.

climbs.name: Crack in the Track
climbs.fa: Opened; Greg Collins, Brady Johnston, Nick Mastri

content.description:
The lowest exposed rock of the Grand Teton: Crack in the Track is an avalanche scrubbed pitch of high difficulty. More Extreme difficulty awaits on the extension. A strong climb to practice very difficult movements in a high ambience environment.  A V6 boulder at the start is followed by 5.11+ to reach the crack. 2 distinct cruxes in the sustained crack to reach the lower off 8a. Extension above is unsent.

Do not climb here when there is risk of the Grand Teton avalanching full track.
content.protection: Very good protection but a locking carabiner and stick would make it even better.
content.location: North fork Garnet Canyon above the Meadows, west of Spalding Falls, in the avalanche path of the Grand Teton. West face of Y Slab.

content.description: Rough bloc 100m east of Middle Teton Cave Route. Undercut east facing line following a vertical white band.
content.location:
100m east of Middle Teton Cave Route, in an ablating talus basin.

This is a rapidly changing area, settlement, ablation, avalanche runout, angle may vary.

pathTokens: Garnet Canyon Rock Climbs-Not Disappointment Peak
